InfoText: After finishing this lesson,  you will be able to...
[ encode and decode airlines.
[ encode and decode cities and airports.
[ encode and decode equipment.
[ encode and decode countries.
<PgDn>
The term itinerary refers to all the departure points,  connecting points,  and
destinations in a trip. The following itinerary consists of 2 segments:
1.^Paris^ -^ London^
2.^London^ -^ Paris^
This itinerary is a round trip. The first segment is called the outbound
segment,  and the second segment is called the return segment.
<PgDn>
City codes and airport codes are used to indicate the board point and off
point of each segment,  as follows:
MADPAR^
Board point~~~~{  }~~~~Off point
This city pair would indicate a segment from Madrid (MAD to Paris (PAR.
<PgDn>
The transaction code DAN^ is used to encode a city,  as follows:
DAN^MADRID
Encode city~~~~{   }~~~~City name
This entry will display the city code for Madrid. Input this entry now.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: The response gives the 3-letter IATA code,  the code indicator,  and the
name. The C after the code indicates that the code is a city code. The A
in the next line indicates the airport code. The country code is shown on
the far right. Now encode the city Munich.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: The transaction code DAC^ is used to decode a city or airport code,  as
follows:
DAC^FLR
Decode city~~~~{  }~~~~City code
Input this entry now.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: Now input the entry to decode the city code DUR.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: Encode the city Bremen.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: Now input the entry to decode the city code PAR.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: Some cities have multiple airports. In this case,  each airport has a
different code. In this example,  PAR is the city code for Paris,  whereas
CDG is the code for the Charles de Gaulle airport. Now encode the city
Barcelona.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: Each airline has a two-letter code. To encode an airline,  type DNA^ followed
by the airline's name,  as follows:
DNA^AMERICA WEST
Encode airline~~~~{      }~~~~Airline name
This entry will display the airline code for America West. Input this entry.
The response shows the 2-letter carrier code,  the 3-letter code,  the
3-digit numeric code,  and the name of the airline. The transaction code
DNA^ is also used to decode an airline code,  as follows:
DNA^CX
This entry will decode the airline code CX. Input this entry now.
Now decode the airline code OS.
Encode the airline Aer Lingus.
Decode the airline code JU.
Each passenger aircraft has a three-letter equipment code. The transaction
code DNE^ is used to encode aircraft equipment,  as follows:
DNE^FOKKER F27
This entry will display the equipment code for Fokker F27 aircraft. Input
this entry now.
The entry code DNE^ is also used to decode an equipment code,  as follows:
DNE^DH8
Decode the equipment code M80.
Encode the equipment Cessna.
Now decode the equipment code GRG.
The entry code DC^ is used to encode or decode a country,  as follows:
DC^JAPAN
This entry will display the country code for Japan. Input this entry now.
The response shows the 2-letter country code,  the country name,  the
region,  and the IATA traffic conference area. The ISO currency code is
also displayed. The transaction code DC^ is also used to decode a country
Input the entry to decode the country code IT.
Let's review. Encode the airline Egyptair.
Display the city code for Brussels.
Decode the carrier code AY.
Decode the city code STR.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: Decode the equipment code 744.
Display the country code for Canada.
You have reached the end of the lesson. Repeat this lesson until
you can finish without requesting help.
<PgDn>
After finishing this lesson,  you will be able to...
[ display neutral availability for a specific date and city pair.
[ interpret the information in an availability display.
[ specify the departure time.
<PgDn>
The transaction code AN^ is input to obtain a neutral display of available
flights for a specific date and city pair. For example,  the following entry
will display flights departing on 24 January from Frankfurt to Paris:
AN24JANFRAPAR^
City pair~~~~~~~~~{"
Input this entry now.
If a city code is input for a multi-airport city,  AMADEUS will display
flights for all local airports. Display availability for flights departing
on 26 August from PAR to MAD.
The heading identifies the display as an AMADEUS availability display. The
code AN^ indicates that neutral availability is displayed. The number of
days between the current date and the departure date is also shown. The
flights in this display will depart 21 days after the current date. The
heading also shows the day of the week and the departure date. The 4 digits
on the end of the heading indicate the departure time. AMADEUS will display
the first flights departing within 1 hour of this time. If no departure time
is specified,  0000 is assumed.
<PgDn>
Each flight has a line number. The carrier code and flight number are shown
after the line number. In this example,  the flight in line 1 is Iberia 3409,
and the flight in line 2 is Air France 1142. The colon (: in line 3 indicates
a duplicate flight listing operated under multiple airline codes. In this
example,  IT 8530 is the same flight as AF 1142.
<PgDn>
The columns to the right of the flight number show the number of seats that
may be sold in one transaction with immediate confirmation. This information
is called the seat quota. The maximum number of seats shown in each class
depends on the carrier's agreement with AMADEUS. On these flights,  up to 9
seats may be confirmed immediately in one transaction. A slash after the
seat quota indicates that last-seat availability is displayed. This code is
called the dynamic availability indicator.
<PgDn>
The next columns show the airport and terminal where each flight departs.
The fight in line 1 departs from Orly from terminal S,  whereas the flight
in line 2 departs from Charles de Gaulle from terminal 2D.
<PgDn>
The next column shows the airport and terminal where each flight arrives.
The flight in line 1 arrives at Madrid at the international terminal.
<PgDn>
The departure time and arrival time are shown after the off point. The
flight in line 1 departs at 0705 and arrives at 0900. The local time is
displayed for each point.
<PgDn>
The number of stops and the equipment code are displayed after the flight
times. The slash (/ after the number of stops indicates that the carrier
is an AMADEUS Access carrier. All the flights in this example are nonstop.
<PgDn>
The AMADEUS access indicator may be one of the following:
/^          AMADEUS Access
.^          AMADEUS Access Sell
:^          AMADEUS Access Update
*^          AMADEUS Direct Access
<PgDn>
A slash (/ indicates that the actual number of available seats are displayed
in each class,  up to 9 seats per class. If a reservation is booked,  it will
be confirmed immediately by the airline. A dot (. indicates that the actual
number of available seats is not displayed. However,  if a reservation is
booked,  it will be confirmed immediately.
<PgDn>
A colon (: indicates that the AMADEUS display is synchronized with the
airline's reservation system. If a reservation is booked,  a message will
be sent notifying the airline. An asterisk (* indicates that the actual
number of available seats can be obtained from the airline by means of
a special direct-access entry.
<PgDn>
Which code indicates that the actual number of available seats is displayed,
to a maximum of 9 per class?
The equipment code is displayed to the right of the AMADEUS Access
indicator. The flight in line 1 is operated with Airbus 343 aircraft.
<PgDn>
The total elapsed flight time is displayed on the right. The flight in
line 1 has an elapsed time of 1 hour,  55 minutes.
<PgDn>
Assume a client plans to travel on 19 March from Frankfurt to Vienna.
Display neutral availability.
Display neutral availability on 30 January from Madrid to Lisbon.
A departure time may be specified as follows:
AN22MARBRUNCE0800^
When this entry is input,  AMADEUS will search for the flights departing
within one hour of 0800. Input this entry now.

TerminalText: 4   SN9377  C9 Y9 M9 L9 K9 T9 QL  BRU   GVA   1710   1820   0/735
InfoText: If a flight has more than 7 booking classes,  the additional classes are
shown on a separate line. In this display,  SN 965 has 8 booking classes.
Connecting flights are shown in line 4. SN 9377 departs from BRU to GVA,
where passengers transfer to SR 758,  which proceeds to NCE.
<PgDn>

to all New York City airports on 29 May?

When flight availability is displayed,  the following entry code may be used
to display availability for return flights:
ACR^

Frankfurt.

departure date. The return date may be input as follows:
ACR25FEB^
This example will display return flights on 25 February. To demonstrate,
assume a client plans to travel from Rome to Madrid on 22 April. He prefers
to depart at about 0800. Display neutral availability.

InfoText: The following entries may be used to change the board point or off point:
ACOSA^                Change board point to OSA
AC//MUC^              Change off point to MUC
Note that AC^ is typed before the new board point,  and AC//^ is typed before
the new off point. Input the entry to change the board point to MIL.

The transaction code AA^ may be used to order flights by arrival time,  as
follows:
AA^18MARMADROM1300
To demonstrate,  display availability by arrival time on 16 July from Milan
to Brussels.

The transaction code AD^ may be used to order flights by departure time,  as
follows:
AD^30JANLHRCDG0900

DUS to CDG,  departing at 1100.
The transaction code AE^ may be used to order flights by elapsed time,  as
follows:
AE^10SEPLONPAR

Frankfurt to Miami.
The following entries may be used to re-order the display:
ACAA^             Re-order flights by arrival time
ACAD^             Re-order flights by departure time
ACAE^             Re-order flights by elapsed time

InfoText: Assume the client prefers the Air France flight departing at 1325. Book
a reservation for 2 passengers in Y class.
The air segment contains information about the flight reservation. The
segment number indicates the order in the itinerary.
<PgDn>
Each flight segment shows the airline code,  flight number,  and class. This
reservation is booked on Air France flight 1159 in Y class.
<PgDn>
The departure date is shown after the booking class. This reservation is
booked for 31 August. The digit after the date indicates the day of the week.
The digit 3 indicates that the flight departs on Wednesday.
<PgDn>
The board point and off point are displayed after the date. This flight
departs from Barcelona and arrives at Charles de Gaulle.
<PgDn>
The segment status is displayed before the number of seats. The status code HK^
indicates that the reservation is confirmed.
<PgDn>
The local departure time and arrival time are displayed after the number of
seats. This flight will depart from Barcelona at 1325 and arrive at Charles
de Gaulle at 1515.
<PgDn>
In this Air France segment,  the latest check-in time and the departure
terminal are shown before the departure time. Passengers are advised to
check in no later than 1255 at terminal A.
<PgDn>
The equipment code,  number of stops,  and meal code are displayed after
the flight times.
<PgDn>
Any applicable service information is displayed on the line directly below
the air segment. In this example,  AF 1159 will arrive at Terminal 2D. Input
the entry to ignore the transaction.
Now display neutral availability on 14 March from Munich to all London
airports.
Book 4 seats in H class on the flight that departs at 1030.
In this segment,  the status code HK4^ indicates that 4 seats are now confirmed.
Input the entry to ignore the transaction.

applies. The service information may be displayed as follows:
RTSVC^
Input this entry.

After finishing this lesson,  you will be able to...
[ sell a flight by carrier,  flight number,  booking class,
date,  and routing.
[ input an information-only segment.

<PgDn>
The transaction code SS^ is used to sell a flight without checking
availability,  as follows:
SS^KL243H10MAYAMSFRA1
This entry will book a reservation on KL^ 243^ in H^ class on 10MAY^ from AMS^
to FRA^ for 1 passenger. Input this entry.
The following entry will book a reservation on LH^ 1050^ in B^ class on 13MAY^
from FRA^ to DUS^ for 1^ passenger:
SSLH1050B13MAYFRADUS1^
Note that SS^ is typed before the airline code and the number of seats is
typed after the destination point. Input this entry.
Now book a reservation on KL 222 in H class on 16MAY from DUS to AMS for 1
passenger.
Note that the Lufthansa segment has the status HK^ indicating that the
reservation is confirmed. The KLM segments have the status SS^ indicating
that the seats will be confirmed when the transaction is ended. Ignore
the transaction.
Now book a reservation on NZ 14 in Y class on 12JUN from AKL to SYD for 2
passengers.
Book a reservation on AN 161 in Y class on 17JUN from SYD to PER. The number
of passengers must be the same on all flight segments.
Now book a reservation on AN 28 in Y class on 21JUN from PER to MEL.
Book a reservation on NZ 128 in Y class on 24JUN from MEL to AKL.
Ignore the transaction.
Occasionally,  an agent may book a segment directly with the airline by
phone,  rather than through AMADEUS. The status code PK^ may be used to
insert a passive segment in the itinerary,  as follows:
SSJL401C15JULNRTLHRPK2/11451540/RWGDDF^
The flight times and the reservation code (called the record locator are
typed after the number of seats. Input this entry.
Now insert a passive segment for FI 451 in Y class on 22JUL from LHR to
KEF for 2 passengers,  departing at 1300 and arriving at 1555. The record
locator is 2FR9GH.
Ignore the transaction.
An open^ segment^ is a booked segment on a specific carrier over a specific
routing,  on an unknown flight or date. The transaction code SO^ is used to
book an open segment,  as follows:
SOIBCBCNMAD^
This entry will book an open segment on IB in C class from BCN to MAD.
Input this entry.
Ignore the transaction.
Book a reservation on BA 5019 in M class on 18MAR from BRU to MAN for 1
passenger.
Assume the passenger wants to book an open segment on BA in M class
from MAN to BRU.
Ignore the transaction.
An open segment may be booked for a specific date as follows:
SOLHL12MARTXLLHR^
This entry will book an open segment for travel on LH in L class on 12 March
from TXL to LHR. Input this entry.
Ignore the transaction.
Assume a passenger wants to book an open segment for travel on SK in M class
on 25 April from FRA to CPH.
Ignore the transaction.
An information segment gives the details of a flight not booked through
AMADEUS. The transaction code SI^ is used to insert an information segment,
as follows:
SINI909Y25NOVBRULISHK2^
Information segments are not used by AMADEUS for pricing,  ticketing,  or
message generation. The example above shows that 2 seats are confirmed (HK
on NI^ 909^ in Y^ class on 25NOV^ from BRU^ to LIS^. Input this entry.
Assume the passengers have booked a confirmed reservation on NG 6257 in Y
class on 30 November from LIS to BCN. Input an information segment in the
itinerary.
Assume the passengers have booked a confirmed reservation on BQ 803 in Y
class on 5 December from BCN to BRU. Input an information segment in the
itinerary.
Ignore the transaction.
Let's review. Book a reservation on OA 344 in Y class on 26 May from RUH to
ATH for 2 passengers.
Assume a reservation has already been booked on KL 104 in S class departing
on 30 May from ATH to AMS for 2 passengers. Input the reservation as an
information-only segment.
Now book an open segment on AF in M class on 2 April from AMS to CDG.
Ignore the transaction.

After finishing this lesson,  you will be able to...
[ place a request for seats on a carrier's waitlist.
[ input a manual waitlisted segment.
[ enter a surface (ARNK segment for continuity.
<PgDn>
If a desired booking class is sold out,  but the waitlist is open,  seats may
be placed on the carrier's waitlist for that flight. The availability status
code L^ indicates that seats may be waitlisted. To demonstrate,  display
neutral availability on 17 May from FRA to PAR departing at 0900.

TerminalText: 2   AF1445  C9 Z2 YL SL KL HL TL  FRA 2 CDG2D 1025   1135   0/AB3       1:10
3   AF1441  C9 Z2 YL SL KL HL TL  FRA 2 CDG2D 1210   1320   0/735       1:10
InfoText: Assume the clients prefer the Air France flight departing at 1025. The
availability status L^ indicates seats may be waitlisted in Y class. The
code PE^ is used to book a waitlisted segment,  as follows:
SS1Y2/PE^
This entry will waitlist 1 seat in Y class on the flight in line 2. Input
this entry.
The status HL^ indicates a waitlisted flight segment. An alternative
reservation should be booked to ensure that the passenger has a confirmed
booking for his departure. Input MPAN^ to redisplay the availability
display. Then book 1 seat in Y class on the flight in line 5.
The passenger is now waitlisted on AF 1445 and confirmed on AF 1405. If the
waitlisted segment is confirmed later,  you would then cancel the duplicate
reservation. Ignore the transaction.
Display neutral availability on 20 May from STO to LON,  departing at 1100.

TerminalText: 7 AYTQ 575  C9 S9 Z9 M9 G9 T9 K9  ARN 2 LGW S 1530   1705   0/D95       2:35
InfoText: Assume the passengers prefer the SK flight departing at 1110. Waitlist
2 seats in S class.
Input MPAN^ to redisplay the availability display. Then book a confirmed
reservation for 2 seats in S class on the flight in line 5.
The passenger is now waitlisted on SK 531 and confirmed on SK 527. Ignore
the transaction.
The code PE^ is used to waitlist a segment by carrier and flight number,
as follows:
SSAF882Y30APRORYLHRPE1^
The priority waitlist code PE^ is typed before the number of seats. Study
the example. Then input the entry to waitlist 2 seats on SN 951 in Y class
on 27AUG from BRU to AMS.
The status code PE^ will be changed to HL^ when the transaction is ended.
Ignore the transaction.
Input the entry to waitlist one seat on TP 555 in Y class on 13 June from
FRA to LIS.
Now book a confirmed reservation on TP 775 in Y class for the same date and
city pair. Book the same number of seats.
Ignore the transaction.
Display availability by departure time on 23 June from Charles de Gaulle
to Frankfurt,  departing at 0700.
Book a confirmed reservation for one passenger in Y class on the AF flight
departing at 0735.
Assume the passenger will travel by train from Frankfurt to Dusseldorf and
then board a flight to Paris. When the departure point of a flight segment
is different from the arrival point of the preceding segment,  an ARNK^
(arrival unknown segment should be input for continuity.
<PgDn>
An ARNK segment is input as follows:
SIARNK^
Input this entry.
The ARNK segment indicates that the departure point of the next flight is
different from the arrival point of the previous flight. Display
availability by departure time on 29 June from DUS to CDG departing
Book a confirmed reservation for one passenger in Y class on the AF flight
departing at 1335.
The ARNK segment maintains continuity between the arrival point of
segment 1 and the departure point of segment 2. Ignore the transaction.

airports to Madrid.

<PgDn>
After finishing this lesson,  you will be able to...
[ input passenger names.
[ input multiple passengers with the same surname.
[ input a child or infant name.
<PgDn>
Details about client reservations are stored in passenger name records,  or"
PNRS. Each PNR contains information such as the passenger names,  contact
telephone numbers,  ticketing details,  and the person who requested the
service. Each item of information is stored in a separate PNR element.
<PgDn>
A PNR can be retrieved by the passenger's surname,  as follows:
RT/COLUMBUS^
This entry will retrieve the PNR for the surname Columbus. Note that RT/^
is typed before the name. Input this entry.
Every PNR has an itinerary. The passenger's name,  contact telehone
numbers,  and the ticketing arrangement are also stored in the PNR.
<PgDn>
The name^ element^ shows the names of the passengers.
<PgDn>
A contact telephone number is stored in the contact^ element^. The label AP^
identifies this element. The client's business phone is stored in this PNR.
<PgDn>
Ticketing details are stored in the ticketing^ element^. The label TK^
identifies this element. In this example,  the code TL^ indicates the date
for ticketing.
<PgDn>
Ignore the transaction to remove the PNR from the work area.
The entry code NM^ is used to input a passenger name,  as follows:
NM^1DRAKE/FRANCIS MR
The number of passengers in the entry is typed before the surname. This
entry will input the passenger name Mr. Francis Drake. Input this entry.
Ignore the transaction.
Either the given name or initial may be input. Input the name entry for
Mrs. G. Koenig.
Ignore the transaction.
A title such as MR or MRS should be included for clarity. The following
titles are commonly used:
MR^         Male/adult
MRS^        Female/married
MISS^       Female/not married
MS^         Female/marital status unknown
MSTR^       Male/child
<PgDn>
Input the name entry for Miss C. Topolos.
Ignore the transaction.
Multiple passengers with the same surname are input as follows:
NM2HUBBARD/C^ MR/H^ MRS^
A slash is typed before each passenger's initial. This entry will input
the names Mr. C. Hubbard and Mrs. H. Hubbard. The surname is typed just
once. Input this entry.
Ignore the transaction.
Now input the name entry for Mr. J. Spratt and Mrs. L. Spratt. Remember to
type the number of passengers before the surname.
Ignore the transaction.
The code (CHD^ is used to identify a child from 2 to 12 years of age,  as
follows:
NM2DUPREE/ANNE^ MRS/MARIE^ (CHD^
In this entry,  Marie Dupree is identified as a child. When this entry is
input,  AMADEUS will send a message notifying each airline that a child
will be travelling. Input this entry.
Ignore the transaction.
Input the name entry for Mr. P. Smith,  Mrs R. Smith,  and a child,  N. Smith.
Ignore the transaction.
The code (INF^ is used to identify an infant under 2 years of age,  as
follows:
NM1RUIZ/CARMEN^ MRS^ (INF/MARIA^
This entry indicates that Mrs. Carmen Ruiz will travel with her infant,
Maria. Note that the infant is not included in the number of passengers.
Input this entry.
Ignore the transaction.
Assume Mr. Hans Fjeld and Mrs. Ann Fjeld will travel with their infant,
Ingmar. Input the passenger names.
Ignore the transaction.
Passengers with different surnames may be input with one entry,  as
follows:
NM1WILLIAMS/J^ MR1THOMAS/P^ MR^
This entry will input the names Mr. J. Williams and Mr. P. Thomas. The
number of passengers with each same surname is typed before the surname
of each passenger. Input this entry.
Ignore the transaction.
Let's review. What entry would be used to input the passenger name Mr. J.
Heilman?
Input the name entry for Mr. C. Martinez and Mrs. J. Martinez,
travelling with a child,  P. Martinez.
Input the name entry for Mrs. Gina Franco travelling with her infant,
Paulo.
With one entry,  input the names Mr. J. Klein and Mr. R. Peters.
You have reached the end of the lesson. Repeat this lesson until
you can finish without requesting help.

After finishing this lesson,  you will be able to...
[ input contact telephone numbers.
[ identify location indicators used in phone entries.
[ include passenger association.
<PgDn>
The entry code AP^ is used to input contact phone numbers,  as follows:
Note that the city code is typed before the telephone number. In this
example,  the code -B^ identifies the number as the client business phone.
Input this entry.
A home contact phone is input as follows:
The location indicator -H^ identifies the number as a business phone. Input
this entry.
Ignore the transaction.
The following location codes are used in phone entries:
A^   Travel agency
B^   Business contact
H^   Home contact
<PgDn>
Normally,  it is not necessary to input the agency's phone. AMADEUS
automatically communicates the city,  telephone number,  and agency name
to each airline in the itinerary. Make the entry to store the Barcelona
business phone 03 3442923.
Now input the Barcelona home phone 03 3713543.
Ignore the transaction.
Input the passenger name Mr. Karl Morantz.
Input the Frankfurt business phone 069 373745.
Now input the Frankfurt home phone 069 470292.
Ignore the transaction.
Input the passenger names Mr. P. Blanc and Mr. G. Dupres. Input both names
with one entry.
Assume Mr. Blanc's home phone in Paris is 45678322. The contact element
is input as follows:
The code /P1^ refers to passenger 1,  identifying the phone as that of Mr.
Blanc. Input this entry.
Assume Mr. Dupres's home phone in Paris is 44726531. Input the contact
element.
The code /P1^ identifies the first home phone as that of Mr. Blanc,  and /P2^
identifies the second home phone as that of Mr. Dupres. These codes are
called the passenger^ association^. Ignore the transaction.
Display neutral availability from all Paris airports to Madrid on 19 May.
Sell 2 seats Y class on the Air France flight departing from CDG at 0920.
The passengers are Mr. C. Gomez and Mrs. R. Gomez. Input the names.
Mr. Gomez's business phone in Madrid is 01 3841983. Input the phone and
include the correct passenger association code.
If all passengers have the same phone,  passenger association may be omitted.
Input the Madrid home phone 01 4622243.
Ignore the transaction.

<PgDn>
After finishing this lesson,  you will be able to...
[ input a ticketing element.
[ indicate the ticketing office.
<PgDn>
The entry code TK^ is used to input a ticketing arrangement,  as follows:
TKTL15JUN^
The code TL^ is used to arrange ticketing on a specified date. Input this
entry.
The code TL^ indicates the last date on which tickets may be purchased.
Input the entry to ignore the transaction.
The following are example of other ticketing arrangement codes:
OK^                   Tickets have been issued
MA^                   Tickets to be mailed
PT^                   Prepaid ticket
AT^                   Airport ticket
Input the entry to arrange an airport ticket for 16 February.
Ignore the transaction.
The office identification code can be included,  as follows:
TKTL24JUN/FRALH0989^
If no office identification is input,  the system defaults to the office
where the ticketing element was input. Make the entry to arrange ticketing"
on 22 March. Include the office identification code PARAF0991.
Ignore the transaction.
Assume a client wants to travel on 16 March from Frankfurt to Fiumicino.
He prefers to depart at 0900. Display neutral availability.
Assume the passenger wants one seat in C class on the Lufthansa flight
departing at 0930.
Assume the client wants to purchase the ticket on 11 March. Input the
ticketing arrangement.
Ignore the transaction.
A client plans to travel from Brussels to Athens on 13 March. Display
neutral availability.

After finishing this lesson,  you will be able to...
[ store a received-from element.
[ end the transaction.
<PgDn>
The received-from element identifies the person who requested the service.
The transaction code RF^ is used to input a received-from element,  as
follows:
RF^MRBRAUN
This entry indicates that Mr. Braun requested the service. Input this
entry. Note that the text does not include any spaces. If a space is input,
it will be deleted by the system. Input this entry.
The received-from element is displayed initially below the responsible
office identification code. However,  when the transaction is ended,  this
element is no longer displayed. Ignore the transaction.
Input the name^ entry^ for Mr. L. Schindler.
The abbreviation P^ or PAX^ may be used if the passenger requested his own"
reservation. This entry is input as follows:
RFP^
Input this entry.
The received-from element is free-format. Ignore the transaction.
Input the name entry for Mrs. P. Larsen.
Assume the passenger's assistant,  Mr. Svenson,  requested the reservation.
Input the received-from element.
Ignore the transaction.
Input the name entry for Mr. N. Patel.
Assume the passenger requested the reservation. Input the received-from entry.
Ignore the transaction.
